origination.corpname: Bureau of Social Hygiene. (New York, N.Y.)

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged in six series, as follows:
Series 5 - New York Police Psychopathic Laboratory

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: The Bureau of Social Hygiene resulted from the appointment of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., to a Special Grand Jury to investigate white slavery in New York City in 1910. In conferences taken in the course of this investigation, Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., became convinced that for a lasting improvement of conditions a permanent organization was needed. On March 22, 1911, The Committee of Three, including Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., Paul Warburg, and Starr Murphy, met. The name "Bureau of Social Hygiene" was first used in October of that year, but not consistently until 1913.

In 1913 the Bureau was incorporated and its purpose was stated as "...the study, amelioration, and prevention of those social conditions, crimes, and diseases which adversely affect the well being of society, with special reference to prostitution and the evils associated therewith." The Bureau would engage in research and education, publish reports, and employ and/or cooperate with other public or private agencies to obtain these goals. The emphasis in the years from 1911 until the reorganization of 1928 was mainly on prostitution, the control of vice, and, through that, the relationships to police organization. Narcotics was also an early interest. Throughout these early years, Katherine Bement Davis, Commissioner of Charities and Correction of New York and later Superintendent of Bedford Hills Reformatory, guided the Bureau as General Secretary.

Miss Davis resigned in 1928 and Lawrence B. Dunham was appointed Director. Under Mr. Dunham's administration, from 1928-1934, the Bureau developed a broadened interest in criminology. In 1929 the certificate of incorporation was amended and the emphasis on prostitution was dropped. Criminology embraced crime reporting, police training and education, penology, criminal law, and juvenile delinquency. While studies and projects were still conducted in narcotics and social hygiene, the main thrust of the organization was crime and criminology.

The Bureau functioned through grants. It was not a foundation and had no set endowment. In the very early years of its existence, financial backing came from several sources including Paul Warburg, the New York Foundation, and John D. Rockefeller, Jr., although throughout the history of the Bureau, Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., was always the main contributor. Grants were occasionally channeled through the Bureau from the Spelman Fund of New York and the Rockefeller Foundation.

Grants were made by the Bureau for a variety of types of work. Research studies were conducted, such as the Institute of Criminology and the Crew Study; books were published, such as "European Police Systems" and "Policewoman's Handbook"; fellowships were given, as were the fellowships in prison study; and experiments were conducted at the Massachusetts State Prison Colony and the Laboratory of Social Hygiene at Bedford Hills. Grants were most often long range covering periods of from three to five years. Although the Bureau did not interfere in the conduct of a project once money had been granted, it was careful in its selection of projects and kept in close touch during the life of the project.

The Bureau ceased making new appropriations in 1934 and by mid-1937 all the previous commitments had been brought to a close. Annual meetings were held until 1940 when the Bureau was dissolved on November 13th.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important subjects in this collection include: prostitution and white slavery, penal institutions and systems, juvenile delinquency, criminal law, police systems, police training, public administration, narcotics laws and control nationally and internationally, maternal health, sex education, birth control, uniform crime statistics, the relation of mental illness to crime, scientific criminal investigations, probation and parole.

Among the correspondents are: Raymond B. Fosdick, Starr Murphy, Arthur Woods, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Henry Aslinger, William Draper Lewis, John D. Rockefeller, 3rd, Abraham Flexner, Walter L. Treadway, Felix Frankfurter, J. Edgar Hoover, George Wickersham, Katharine B. Davis, Leonard V. Harrison, Franklin D. Roosevelt, James Bronson Reynolds, Lawrence B. Dunham, and Alfred E. Smith.

It was not the Bureau's practice to keep the research files from any given project. Thus the records for the Sanger Birth Control Clinic are at Harvard, the Laboratory of Social Hygiene records are at Bedford Hills, and so on.
The Bureau of Social Hygiene Collection covers the period from 1911 to 1940.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: RAC users must abide by all applicable provisions of United States copyright law. Reproduction/duplication of archival items is routinely provided in accordance with "fair use." If the RAC does not hold copyright for an archival collection, or items within a collection, it is the user's responsibility to contact the copyright holder, or make a fair effort to do so, prior to publication.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for researchd. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Processing was completed as of August 1, 1969. Processing Level 3: Standard Processing. All material is available in acid free manuscript boxes and folders.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of the Bureau of Social Hygiene were deposited with the Rockefeller Foundation Archives in January 1938 by Arthur Woods.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of annual reports, dockets, the Bureau history, minutes, and folders for the members and staff of the Bureau. While there is reference to the various projects, the emphasis of this series is on administration policy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains information on the Crew Study.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This folder contains information on the Crew Study.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically and chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series included budgets, accounts, treasurer's reports, royalty information on the publications, and pledges and commitments.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The following Bureau financial records are located in JDR financial material: Ledger, Oct. 1, 1925 Cash Journal and Trial Balance, 1920-1924 Ledger, 1926-January 18, 1928
See also China Medical Board, Inc. Collection, Series 2, Box 5 for Trial Balance, 1928-1930.

did.unittitle: Mt. Kisco National Bank and Trust
Pledges and Commitments - John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also China Medical Board, Inc. Collection, Series 2, Box 5 for Trial Balance, 1928-1930.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in five subseries, as follows:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains project information, as well as general subject information. These files date mainly from the 1928 reorganization through 1935.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Scholarly access to original archival material is permitted. User copies of microfilm are also available. The Projects series is reproduced in the microfilm publication of the Bureau of Social Hygiene project and research files, 1913-1940, reels 1-20 (Scholarly Resources Inc., 1980).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information on publications such as "Dangerous Drugs", the League of Nations Committee, narcotics investigations, and legislation in the area of narcotics control.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries has material on projects such as the Massachusetts State Prison Colony, Associates for Government Service, Uniform Criminal Statistics, Police Training Schools, and the Institute of Criminology at Columbia. It also contains information on publications like "European Policy Systems" and general information on criminology, prisons, and probation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains information not administrative but in which the Bureau had a special interest, such as the Institute for Family Relations, The Ohio Institute, and housing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sunnyside Co-ops (New York City) and Radburn, New Jersey.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Scholarly access to original archival material is permitted. User copies of microfilm are also available. The Leonard V. Harrison Files are reproduced in the microfilm publication of the Bureau of Social Hygiene project and research files, 1913-1940, reels 21-31 (Scholarly Resources Inc., 1980).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in five subseries, as follows:

Subseries 1 - Narcotics (2 boxes) Subseries 2 - European Police Systems (12 boxes) Subseries 3 - Boston-Harvard Survey (4 boxes) Subseries 4 - Criminology (6 boxes) Subseries 5 - Miscellaneous (2 boxes)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Leonard Harrison's own files, as distinct from the Bureau's files. There is much material in this series which relates to studies in Series 3 - Projects. In fact, much of this series is background research for those projects. Research in Series 3 will be more fruitful if this series is also consulted.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series contains the remnant files of the New York Police Psychopathic Laboratory, which were used in conjunction with a study on mental disease and crime. They contain material on cases and drafts of several reports.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Bureau of Social Hygiene resulted from the appointment of John D. Rockefeller, Jr., to a Special Grand Jury to investigate white slavery in New York City in 1910. In conferences taken in the course of this investigation, Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., became convinced that for a lasting improvement of conditions a permanent organization was needed. On March 22, 1911, The Committee of Three, including Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., Paul Warburg, and Starr Murphy, met. The name "Bureau of Social Hygiene" was first used in October of that year, but not consistently until 1913.

In 1913 the Bureau was incorporated and its purpose was stated as "...the study, amelioration, and prevention of those social conditions, crimes, and diseases which adversely affect the well being of society, with special reference to prostitution and the evils associated therewith." The Bureau would engage in research and education, publish reports, and employ and/or cooperate with other public or private agencies to obtain these goals. The emphasis in the years from 1911 until the reorganization of 1928 was mainly on prostitution, the control of vice, and, through that, the relationships to police organization. Narcotics was also an early interest. Throughout these early years, Katherine Bement Davis, Commissioner of Charities and Correction of New York and later Superintendent of Bedford Hills Reformatory, guided the Bureau as General Secretary.

Miss Davis resigned in 1928 and Lawrence B. Dunham was appointed Director. Under Mr. Dunham's administration, from 1928-1934, the Bureau developed a broadened interest in criminology. In 1929 the certificate of incorporation was amended and the emphasis on prostitution was dropped. Criminology embraced crime reporting, police training and education, penology, criminal law, and juvenile delinquency. While studies and projects were still conducted in narcotics and social hygiene, the main thrust of the organization was crime and criminology.

The Bureau functioned through grants. It was not a foundation and had no set endowment. In the very early years of its existence, financial backing came from several sources including Paul Warburg, the New York Foundation, and John D. Rockefeller, Jr., although throughout the history of the Bureau, Mr. Rockefeller, Jr., was always the main contributor. Grants were occasionally channeled through the Bureau from the Spelman Fund of New York and the Rockefeller Foundation.

Grants were made by the Bureau for a variety of types of work. Research studies were conducted, such as the Institute of Criminology and the Crew Study; books were published, such as "European Police Systems" and "Policewoman's Handbook"; fellowships were given, as were the fellowships in prison study; and experiments were conducted at the Massachusetts State Prison Colony and the Laboratory of Social Hygiene at Bedford Hills. Grants were most often long range covering periods of from three to five years. Although the Bureau did not interfere in the conduct of a project once money had been granted, it was careful in its selection of projects and kept in close touch during the life of the project.

The Bureau ceased making new appropriations in 1934 and by mid-1937 all the previous commitments had been brought to a close. Annual meetings were held until 1940 when the Bureau was dissolved on November 13th.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Photographs, slides, and other images are open for scholarly research.

RAC is unable to provide access to obsolete media and original digital media. In addition separated media may not yet have undergone stabilization procedures. When feasible, a digital surrogate may be created via special order. All applicable charges will apply. See RAC Head of Archival Services or RAC Head of Digital Programs for details.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for scholarly research. Materials requiring specialized equipment for access (film, audio, video, slides) may be closed to research dependent on availability of the applicable equipment
Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services/Head of Reference.
